titleStmt.title: A relation of the glorious triumphs and order of the ceremonies, obserued in the marriage of the high and mighty Charles, King of Great Brittaine, and the Ladie Henretta [sic] Maria, sister to the most Christian King of France Together vvith the ceremonie obserued in their troth-plighting, performed in the castle of the Louure, in his Maiesties chamber there. As also the Kings declaration containing a prohibition vnto all his subiects to use any traffique or commerce with the kingdome of Spaine. Published in the Parliament of Paris, the 12. of May, 1625. Whereunto the originall French copie is added.
Ceremonies et solennitez observees en l'eglise de Nostre Dame de Paris, au mariage du roy de la Grand' Bretagne, & de Madame soeur du roy. English and French.

titleStmt.title: A relation of the glorious triumphs and order of the ceremonies, obserued in the marriage of the high and mighty Charles, King of Great Brittaine, and the Ladie Henretta [sic] Maria, sister to the most Christian King of France Together vvith the ceremonie obserued in their troth-plighting, performed in the castle of the Louure, in his Maiesties chamber there. As also the Kings declaration containing a prohibition vnto all his subiects to use any traffique or commerce with the kingdome of Spaine. Published in the Parliament of Paris, the 12. of May, 1625. Whereunto the originall French copie is added.
Ceremonies et solennitez observees en l'eglise de Nostre Dame de Paris, au mariage du roy de la Grand' Bretagne, & de Madame soeur du roy. English and French.

notesStmt.note: A translation of "Ceremonies et solennitez observees en l'eglise de Nostre Dame de Paris, au mariage du roy de la Grand' Bretagne, & de Madame soeur du roy", with the French text following.
The "Kings declaration" is that of Louis XIII.
Cf. Folger catalogue, which gives signatures: A-C‚Å¥.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Henrietta Maria, -- Queen, consort of Charles I, King of England, 1609-1669.

div.p: A RELATION OF THE GLORIOVS TRIVMPHS AND ORDER of the Ceremonies, ob≈øerued in the Marriage of the High and Mighty CHARLES, King of Great Brittaine, and the Ladie HENRETTA MARIA, Si≈øter to the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of France.
TOGETHER WITH THE CEREMONIE ob≈øerued in their Troth-plighting, performed in the Ca≈øtle of the Louure, in his Maie≈øties Chamber there.

AS ALSO THE KINGS DECLARATION containing a Prohibition vnto all his Subiects to v≈øe any Traffique or Commerce with the Kingdome of Spaine. Publi≈øhed in the Parliament of Paris, the 12. of May, 1625.

p.hi: Whereunto the Originall French Copie is added.

div.p: LONDON‚ñ™ Printed by T. S. for Nathaniel Butter, and are to be ≈øold at the ≈øigne of the Pyde-Bull, neere S. Au≈øtens Gate, 1625.

div.head: THE GLORIOVS TRIVMPH AND ORDER OF THE Ceremonies ob≈øerued in the Marriage of the High and Mightie CHARLES King of Great Britaine, and the Lady HENRETTA MARIA, Si≈øter to the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of FRANCE.
div.p: NOW at la≈øt, God being fauourable vnto our Countrey of France, hath plea≈øed to grant what wee mo≈øt de≈øired ≈øo long ≈øince; and tho≈øe thicke cloudes which ≈øeemed to ob≈øcure the lu≈øtre of our Country, and had as it were con≈øpired to kill the fruite thereof in the very blo≈ø≈øome, are now ≈øcattered and blowne ouer, together with the bad influence which threatned vs, God in his ≈øecret will permitting that two of the mo≈øt mighty and potent Kingdomes of Chri≈øtendome, ≈øhould be vnited together, by the mo≈øt glorious Marriage that euer was ≈øeene in the world. Therefore now our Inuincible King Lewis the Iu≈øt, mu≈øt needes promi≈øe to him≈øelfe all felicity, glory and happine≈ø≈øe heaped vpon him by this Vnion.

What great contentment hath France, and Great Britaine profit, to ≈øee them≈øelues ≈øo in≈øeparably vnited, by a more vndi≈ø≈øoluable knot then the Gordian, and by a friend≈øhip better cimmented together, then the Stones of the Babilonian walles, founded by Semiramis? For neuer ≈øhall
any enemies be found ≈øtrong enough to ≈øhake two ≈øo flouri≈øhing Kingdomes, which deriue their greatne≈ø≈øe from heauen, and their limits from the circumference of the Globe: Let all good Frenchmen now then reioyce, at ≈øuch time as the aduer≈øaries of our State, trembling with amazement and feare, haue their very ≈øoules afflicted with ≈øo goodly an alliance: And that I may leaue an eternall memory thereof vnto all po≈øterity, I will mo≈øt ≈øuccinctly here declare, the magnificent triumphes and true manner of this happy marriage.

ON Thur≈øday, the 8. day of May, the King came forth into his Chamber, and there appeared like the glorious Sunne, out-≈øhining the other Starres, hauing his Queene with him, his ≈øecond light: the Prince his onely brother, my Lords the Dukes of Nemours, and of Elbeuf, the Mar≈øhals of Vitry and Ba≈ø≈øompiere, with other Lords of his Court, and ≈øent for the Ladie his Si≈øter, who came thither accompanyed with the Queene her mother, the Prince≈ø≈øes of Conde and of County; the Dutche≈ø≈øes of Gui≈øe, of Cheureu≈øe, and Elbeuf, with many other great Ladies. Her Gowne was of cloth of gold and ≈øiluer, all poudered ouer with Flower-deluces of gold, and enriched with many Diamonds, and other precious ≈øtones, and her traine was borne vp by the yong Ladie of Burbon.

As ≈øhe entred into the Kings Chamber, with a Maie≈øtie corre≈øpondent to her birth, my Lords the Earls of Carlile & Holland, Emba≈ø≈øadours for the King of Great Britaine, came likewi≈øe al≈øo in, as richly clad as can po≈ø≈øibly be expre≈ø≈øed, giuing vnto the King the Contract of Marriage, which was read alowd by the Lord Chancellour, after the King had agreed vnto the Couenants. This done, the Amba≈ø≈øadours with-drew them≈øelues into the Duke of Cheureu≈øe his Chamber, which was ouer the Kings, and hauing communicated
the Contract vnto him: He forthwith repaired vnto his Maie≈øtie, accompanied with the afore-≈øaid Amba≈ø≈øadors, and many other great Lords, apparelled in a Sute of Blacke, the Paines whereof were all garni≈øhed with Diamonds, and the very tags of his points were enriched with the like.

Being come before his Maie≈øtie, he pre≈øented vnto him his Procuration, and the power which the King of great Brittaine had giuen him, which was in≈øerted at the end of the ≈øaid Contract, which the King ≈øigned, and the Lady, both the Queenes, my Lord the Duke of Cheureu≈øe, and the Lords Amba≈ø≈øadors likewi≈øe. This done my Lord the Cardinall De la Roche Foucault made them ≈øure, after the manner accu≈øtomed.

Now as ≈øuch an vnion as this could not be performed without great pompe, and infinite ioy and contentment: So our Ladies Church was cho≈øen for the Ceremonies of the accompli≈øhment of the Marriage and was hung with rich tapi≈øtry and cloth of Gould and Siluer Ti≈ø≈øue.

Then was there a faire and long Gallery rai≈øed, beginning at the entry of the Archbi≈øhops pallace, and reached euen vnto the Quire of the ≈øaid Church: This gallery was vnder-propped with many pillers, which were couered at the top with Violet-colour Sattin, embrodered with golden Flowre-deluces, and below with faire fine lynnen, trimmed with waxe, through this ≈øame pa≈ø≈øed along all the Ceremonies of the Marriage as followeth.

Fir≈øt, the hundred Sui≈ø≈øers of the Kings Guard, clothed in his Maie≈øties Lyuery, their Drumbe beating and their En≈øigne di≈øplayed. After them 12. Haulbois clothed in the like lyuery, which raui≈øhed the hearts of the hearers. Then eight Drumbes couered with the like, which were ≈øo lu≈øtily beaten vp, that the mo≈øt coward courages were animated with the noy≈øe thereof.

Ten Trumpets al≈øo ≈øounded ≈øo merrily that it reioyced all the hearers. Then followed Mon≈øieur de Rhodes, great Mai≈øter of the Ceremonies, brauely apparelled, and well accompanied. After him marched my Lords the Knights of the Order of the Holy Gho≈øt, all gli≈øtering with precious ≈øtones. Then came ≈øeauen Heraulds of Armes with their Coats of Red Crim≈øon Veluet, powdered all ouer with golden Flower-deluces.

Then followed them my Lords of Vitry and Ba≈ø≈øompiere, Mar≈øhals of France: After them my Lord the Duke of Elbeuf. Then my Lord the Duke of Cheureu≈øe, apparelled in a Sute of Blacke-Cloath, cut and lyned with cloath of Gould, with a Cap al≈øo of cloath of Gould, and vpon his head a Iewell, which dazelled the eyes of the beholders, a Scarfe ≈øpotted all ouer with Ro≈øes of Diamonds, with a ≈øhort Cloake all imbroidred with Gold, and powdred with precious ≈øtones.
Then followed both my Lords the Amba≈ø≈øadors Extraordinary of the King of Great Brittaine, &c. clad in cloth of ≈øiluer.

Then came the King of France, in a garment all imbroidred with Gold and Siluer, holding the Lady his Si≈øter in his right hand, who had a crowne vpon her head, and her Gowne powdred all ouer with Flower-deluces of Gold: And Mon≈øieur the Kings Brother on the other ≈øide, who led her in his left hand, being very brauely accoutred.
The Queene Mother followed next.

The Queene her ≈øelfe, in a gowne all imbroidred with Gould, Siluer, and precious ≈øtones. The Prince≈ø≈øes of Conde and of County bearing vp the long Traine of the ≈øame. The young Lady of Montpen≈øier. The Counte≈ø≈øe of Sei≈øons. Madame De Gui≈øe. Madame De Chereu≈øe. Madame De Elbeuf, with many Lords and Ladies, of whom I cannot now make rehear≈øall the number of them was ≈øo great.

All this Royall and generous troupe ≈øtayed at the entry of the great Portall of the ≈øaid Church, before which was a place appointed to celebrate the Marriage in, and whereon was rai≈øed a Canopie of ine≈øtimable vallew, vnder which the King and Mon≈øieur his Brother left the Ladye their Si≈øter, and con≈øigned her into the hands of my Lord the Duke of Chevreu≈øe, and then my Lord Cardinall de la Roche Foucault e≈øpow≈øed the Ladye with the ordinarie ceremonies of the Church.

From thence all the Orders aboue ≈øaid marched into the Quyer through a long Gallerie which was ≈øquared out by a line, in the midde≈øt of the body of the Church all couered with Tapi≈øterie, the riche≈øt that might be.

In the midde≈øt of the ≈øaid Quyer were all ready placed on the one ≈øide vpon emminent ≈øeates, my Lords the Pre≈øidents, hauing their Morters of gold on their heads, and in their ≈øcarlet Robes lyned with Ermines, and the Councellors of the Court of Parliament in the like Gownes.
On the other ≈øide fate alone the Prouo≈øt of the Marchants, in a long Robe of Crim≈øon and violet veluet, being accompanyed with the Shirifes of the Towne.

In the Quyer of the ≈øaid Church, was there moreouer another floore rai≈øed three ≈øteps high, vpon which was another great Canopie, where the King, the Queenes, and Mon≈øieur the Kings Brother were placed and conducted by the fore-named Duke of
Chevreu≈øe & the Amba≈ø≈øadours, who withdrew them≈øelues into the Archbi≈øhops Pallace vntill the Seruice was ended, and then afterwards returned to the King and the Queenes.
Prayers being done, they returned all in the like order as before into the Archbi≈øhops Pallace, where the whole Court ≈øupped.

During which, was heard ≈øuch a noy≈øe and thundring of Cannon, as men would haue iudged that heauen and earth had ioyned together: In the like ≈øort Bon-fires, ≈øquibes, and ≈øuch like were not ≈øpared throughout all the ≈øtreetes: and it may well be verified that France neuer ≈øawe ≈øo much reioycing.
And God I pray, who hath euer beene propitious vnto vs, maintaine our Countrie in her greatne≈ø≈øe, and graunt our King a glorious triumphe ouer his enemies, and a large extent of his Dominions.

div.head: The Order of the Royall Fea≈øt.
div.p: THe Suppper was kept in the Archbi≈øhops great Hall, and the Table reached from the one end thereof vnto the other,

The King ≈øate in the midde≈øt of the Table, ≈øerued by my Lord the great Prior, who repre≈øented the great Ma≈øters per≈øon, before him there marched a number of Drummes, Trumpets and Clairons, accompanyed with Mon≈øieur de Beaumont, great Steward of the Kings Hou≈øe, and thirtie two others Stewards of his Maie≈øties Hou≈øe-hold, with their ≈øtaues in their hands.
The meate was carryed by my Lords the Princes, Dukes, Peeres, and Mar≈øhals of France, followed by the Gentlemen of the Court and their ≈øeruants.
Mon≈øieur de Joinuille ≈øerued as great Pantler, Mon≈øieur d' Elboeuf as Cup-bearer, and my Lord the Earle of Harcourt as Caruer.
The Queene Mother ≈øate on the right hand of the King, ≈øerued by my Lords the Dukes of Belgarde, d'Vzais, and Luxembourg.
The Queene her ≈øelfe on the right hand of the Queene Mother, ≈øerued by my Lords the Dukes d' Alvin, Bri≈ø≈øac, and de Chaune.
The Queene of great Brittaine ≈øate on the Kings left hand, ≈øerued by the Mar≈øhall de Vitry as great Pantler, the Mar≈øhall d' Aubeterre as Cup bearer, and my Lord of Ba≈ø≈øompierre as Caruer.
My Lord the Duke of Chevrou≈øe ≈øate next the Queene of great Brittaine, ≈øerued by the Lord of Rochefort.
The extraordinarie Amba≈ø≈øadous of great Brittaine ≈øate next vnto the afore ≈øaid Duke of Chevreu≈øe.
My Lord the Kings Brother ≈øate neere vnto the Queene, and next them all the Princes, ≈øerued in mo≈øt magnificent and Royall manner.

div.head: The Kings Declaration, contayning a Prohibition vnto all his Subiects, to haue any Trafique or Commerce with the Kingdome of Spaine, Publi≈øhed in the Parliament the 12. of May.

body.p:
LEVVIS by the grace of God King of France and of Nauarre, To all vnto whom the≈øe pre-≈øent Letters ≈øhall come greeting. Vpon the complaints which haue bin made vnto vs by many of our Subiectes traffiquing into Spaine, of a Decree made the 2. of this month by our mo≈øt deare & wellbe-loued Brother, and Brother in law, the Catholique King, vnto his Officers, to ≈øeaze vpon and ≈øtay in all his Ports and Hauens, the Shippes, Goods, and Merchandize of the French (our Subiects:) vnder pretext of Repri≈øals of ≈øome ≈øummes of money, which Our mo≈øt deare and well-beloued Cou≈øin, the Duke
of Gui≈øe, our Gouernour and Lieuetenant Generall in Prouence, did make ≈øtay of certaine Barques, not far from Mar≈øeilles, as belonging vnto ≈øome Genoway MerchaÃÑts: as al≈øo becau≈øe they haunted the de≈øert Hauens of our ≈øaid Country of Prouence, to the preiudice of our Ordinances & Proui≈øions made by Our Court of Parliament of Aix: The ≈øaid King preteÃÑding that ≈øome part of ye ≈øaid mony did appertain vnto his Subiects (which is a thing not yet verified) and part thereof vnto the ≈øaid Genowaies. NOW therefore, becau≈øe it is a matter of great importance for our Subiects good, to preuent them from receauing any further lo≈ø≈øe or hinderance of ≈øuch their ≈øeizure and detention of their Shippes and Goods as is ordained in Spaine, wherein there can be no better order taken, then a generall interdiction of Commerce in tho≈øe places, where the Merchants Our Subiects can no longer be at their libertie. WEE make it knowne, That hauing deliberated of this affayre in Our Councell, where was pre≈øent Our mo≈øt honoured Lady and Mother, ≈øome Princes of Our Blood, other Princes and Officers of Our Crowne, Lords and notable Per≈øonages of Our ≈øayed Councell, WITH THEIR ADVICE, and of Our owne knowledge, full power and royall Authority, We haue made, and doe by the≈øe pre≈øents, ≈øigned with Our hand, make
mo≈øt expre≈ø≈øe prohibition vnto all Our Subiects, of what Quality and Condition ≈øoeuer they be, to haue any Trafique or Commerce in the Kingdome of Spaine, of any Corne, Wine, Cordage, and generaly neither to carry thither, tran≈øport or buy any Merchandize what≈øoeuer, vpon paine vnto the Offenders, of the confi≈øcation of their Ve≈ø≈øels and Goods, and to bee puni≈øhed according to the rigour of Our Lawes: and this to continue vntill a re≈øtitution be fully made of Our Subiects Goods ≈øeazed vpon in Spaine, or that by Our Letters Pattents We ≈øhall otherwi≈øe ordaine.

WHEREFORE Wee charge and command all Our louing and loyall Officers in Our Courts of Parliament, that they cau≈øe the≈øe Our pre≈øent Letters to be read, publi≈øhed and Regi≈øtred, and the contents thereof to bee kept and executed each one apart, and Our general Procurors or their Sub≈øtitutes, to make for the due execution of the ≈øame, all diligent & nece≈ø≈øary per≈øuite and inquirie.

Al≈øo We giue charge vnto Our Gouernors, and Our Liuetenants Generall in Our Prouinces, particuler Captaines and Gouernors of Our Towns and places, chiefely tho≈øe vpon Our Frontiers, and the Bayliffes, Sene≈øhals, and Prouo≈øts of Our mo≈øt deare Cou≈øins, the Con≈øtable & Mar≈øhals of France, or their Lieuetenants, And vnto all Our Iu≈øtices, Officers,
and Subiects, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt vnto the due execution of the≈øe pre≈øents: for ≈øuch is Our plea≈øure.
In Witne≈ø≈øe whereof, Wee haue cau≈øed Our Seale to be put vnto the≈øe afore≈øaid pre≈øents.

date.hi: the 23. of Aprill; in the yeare of Grace, 1625. and of Our Raigne the fifteenth.

closer.signed: Lewis. And vppon the Fowld By the King. De Lomenie.

p.hi: And Sealed with the Great Seale of yellow Waxe, vpon double taile: And vpon the Fowld hereof is written:

body.p: Read, publi≈øhed, and regi≈øtred in Court, yea and the Kings Atturney generall requiring the ≈øame to be put in execution, kept, and ob≈øerued according to their tennor and forme, and collected Copies of the ≈øame to be ≈øent to the Bayliffes and Sene≈øhals of that Iuri≈ødiction, to be there likewi≈øe read, publi≈øhed, and executed by the diligence of the Sub≈øtitutes of the afor≈øaid generall Atturney, which he enioyneth to certifie the Court hereof within the month. In the Parliamement at Paris the 12. of May, 1625.

closer.signed: Signed Du Tillet. Cum Priuiligio Maie≈øtatie

div.head: Le Triomphe glorieux & l'ordre des Ceremonies ob≈øeruees au mariage du Roy de la Grand' Bretagne, & de Madame ≈øoeur du Roy. En≈øemble l'ordre tenu aux fian√ßailles faictes au Cha≈øteau du Louure, en la Chambre de ≈øa Maje≈øt√©.
div.p:
EN fin le ciel propice a la France, a voulu ce qu'elle re≈øpire, il y a ≈øi long temps. Les nuages qui ≈øembloient vouloir ob≈øcurcir ≈øon e≈øclat, & qui auoient comme con≈øpire de faire mourir le fruict en ≈øa fleur, ≈øont maintenant di≈ø≈øipez, & cette mauuai≈øe influence e≈øt aneantie a ce coup, Dicu a permis par vne volonte ≈øecrete, que les deux plus pui≈ø≈øantes Couronnes de la Chre≈øtiente ≈øoient vnies en≈øemble, par le plus celebre mariage qui ≈øe ≈øoit iamais veu dedans l'Vniuers. C'e≈øt donc auiourd'huy que tant de felicite, de gloire, & de bon-heur ne promettent pas moins a no≈øtre grand Roy, inuincible LOVYS LE IVSTE, que l'Empire de tout le monde. Quel contentement a la France, & quel profit a la grand' Bretagne, de ≈øe voir vnies ≈øi in≈øeparablement, par vn noeud plus indi≈ø≈øoluble que le gordien, & par vne amitie mieux cimentee que les murs Babiloniens fondez par Semiramis? Il n'y a point d'ennemis a≈ø≈øez forts pour esbranler iamais deux Royaumes ≈øi flori≈ø≈øans, qui pui≈øent leur grandeur du ciel, & borner leur pui≈ø≈øance de toute la terre. Re≈øioui≈ø≈øons nous donc, bons Fran√ßois, a ce≈øte heure que les aduer≈øaires de l'E≈øtat tremblant de peur & de crainte, ont leur ame ‚Ä¢ migeed vne il belle alliance. Mais pour en lai≈ø≈øer la memoire eternelle, & la donner e≈øt depo≈øt a la po≈øterite. Ie veux de≈øcrire icy
le plus ≈øuccintement qu'il me ≈øera po≈ø≈øible, les magnificences, les triomphes, & l'ordre veritable de cet heureux mariage.

Le Ieudy huictie≈øme iour de May, le Roy paroi≈ø≈øant dedans ≈øa chambre comme vn beau Soleil qui luit au de≈ø≈øus de tous les autres A≈øtres, ayant auec luy la Royne ≈øeconde lumiere, Mon≈øieur ≈øon frere vnique, Me≈ø≈øieurs les Ducs de Nemours & d'Elboeuf, Mare≈øchaux de Vitry & de Ba≈ø≈øom-pierre, & autres Seigneurs de la Cour, enuoya querir Madame, qui y fut a≈ø≈øi≈øtee par la Royne ≈øa mere, Me≈ødames les Prince≈ø≈øes de Conde & de Conty, Me≈ødames les Duche≈ø≈øes de Guy≈øe, de Cheureu≈øe, & d'Elboeuf, & plu≈øieurs autres grandes Dames. Sa robe e≈øtoit de toile d'or & d'argent toute par≈øemee de fleurs de Lys d'or, & enrichie de plu≈øieurs diamants, & autres pierres precieu≈øes. La queue de ladite robe e≈øtoit portee par Madamoi≈øelle de Bourbon.

Comme elle fut entree dedans la chambre du Roy auec vne Maie≈øte digne de ≈øa nai≈ø≈øance, Me≈ø≈øieurs les Comtes de Carlile, & Milor Holand, Amba≈ø≈øadeurs pour le Roy de la Grand' Bretagne, y entrerent au≈ø≈øi to≈øt, ve≈øtus auec le plus bel aduantage qui ≈øe pui≈ø≈øe dire, donnant au Roy le contract de mariage, qui fut leu tout haut par Mon≈øeigneur le Chancelier, apres que ≈øa Maie≈øte eut agree les conuenances. Les Amba≈ø≈øadeurs ≈øe retirerent en la chambre de Mon≈øeigneur le Duc de Cheureu≈øe, au de≈ø≈øus de celle du Roy, & luy ayant fait entendre les accords. Il fut trouuer au≈ø≈øi to≈øt ≈øa Maie≈øtie, accompagne de≈ødits ≈øieurs Amba≈ø≈øadeurs & plu≈øieurs autres Seigneurs de marque, e≈øtant ve≈øtu d'vn habit noir a bandes toutes garnies de diamants, & les fer d'aiguillettes en e≈øtoient enrichis.

Arriue deuant ≈øa Maie≈øte il luy pre≈øenta ≈øa procuration & le pouuoir que luy auoit donne le Roy de la Grand' Bretagne, qui ‚Ä¢ ut inc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce au bout dudit contract de mariage, que le Roy ≈øig ‚Ä¢ a, Madame, les Roynes, Mon≈øeigneur le Duc de Cheureu≈øe, & Me≈ø≈øieurs les Amba≈ø≈øadeurs. Co ‚Ä¢ a fait & arre≈øte,
Mon≈øieur le Cardinal de la Roche-foucaut fit les fian√ßailles a la maniere accou≈øtumee.
Comme vne telle vnion ne ≈øe pouuoit pas paracheuer ≈øans de grandes pompes, & d'infinies re≈øioui≈ø≈øances.
L'Egli≈øe de No≈øtre-Dame fut choi≈øie pour les ceremonies de l'accompli≈ø≈øement du mariage, & fut toute tendue de riches tapi≈ø≈øeries, ti≈ø≈øues de ≈øoye, d'or & d'argent.

L'on e≈øleua enuiron de huict pieds de terre, vne belle & longue gallerie, qui prenoit ≈øon commencement des l'entree de la mai≈øon Archi-Epi≈øcopale, & ≈øe venoit rendre a l'entree du Coeur de ladite Egli≈øe. Elle e≈øtoit ≈øou≈øtenue de plu≈øieurs pilliers, couuerte par le haut de ≈øatin violet, tout brode de fleur de Lys d'or, & par le bas d'vne belle toile de lin ciree, par de≈ø≈øus laquelle pa≈ø≈øerent toutes les ceremonies du mariage, comme il s'en≈øuit.
Premierement, les cent Sui≈ø≈øes des Gardes du corps du Roy, ve≈øtus des liurees de ≈øa Maie≈øte, le tambour battant, & l'en≈øeigne de≈øployee.
Douze haut-bois ve≈øtus de ≈øemblables liurees qui raui≈ø≈øoient par leurs ≈øons agreables les ames par les oreilles.
Huict tambours couuerts de pareilles parures battoient ≈øi furieu≈øement que les courages les moins hardis s'animoient au bruit d'vn tel tintamarre.
Dix trompettes fai≈øoient ≈øauter de ioye & d'alegre≈ø≈øe les coeurs dedans les corps.
Mon≈øieur de Rodes Grand Mai≈øtre des Ceremonies marchoit apres tout cela, ve≈øtu a l'aduantage & fort bien accompagne.
Apres luy Me≈ø≈øieurs les Cheualiers de l'Ordre du S. E≈øprit tous brillans de pierreries.
Sept Herauts d'armes alloient en ≈øuitte auec leur cottes de velours rouge cramoi≈øy fleurdeli≈øees d'or.
Me≈ø≈øieurs de Vitry & de Ba≈ø≈øompierre, Mare≈øchaux de France.
Mon≈øieur le Duc d'Elboeuf.

Mon≈øeigneur le Duc de Cheureu≈øe, ve≈øtu d'vn habit de d ‚Ä¢ ap noir tout couppe & d'ouble de toile d'or auec vne tocque au≈ø≈øi de velours noir, ≈øur ≈øa te≈øte vne en≈øeigne qui esblouy≈ø≈øoit la veue par ≈øon e≈øclat, vne e≈øcrape toute couuerte de ro≈øes de diamants, vn capot tout brode d'or & ≈øeme de pierreries.
Me≈ø≈øieurs les deux Amba≈ø≈øadeurs Extraordinaires, tous deux couuerts de toile d'argent batu auec la toque.
Le Roy auec vn habit tout en broderie d'or & d'argent, tenant a ≈øa main droite Madame, qui auoit vne Couronne ≈øur la te≈øte, & ≈øa robe toute par≈øemee de fleurs de Lys d'or.
Mon≈øieur de l'autre co≈øte qui la tenoit de ≈øa main gauche au≈ø≈øi ≈øuperbement ve≈øtu.
La Royne mere.
La Royne couuerte d'vne robe toute brodee d'or, d'argent & de pierreries.
Me≈ødames les Prince≈ø≈øes de Conde & de Conty, portans la longue queue de ladite robe.
Madamoi≈øelle de Mont-penfier.
Madame la Comte≈ø≈øe de Soi≈ø≈øons.
Madame de Guy≈øe.
Madame de Cheureu≈øe.
Madame d'Elboeuf.
Et tous les autres Seigneurs & Dames de la Cour queie ne peux ≈øpecifier par le menu, tant le nombre e≈øtoit grand.

Toute ce≈øte Royale & genereu≈øe troupe s'arre≈øta a l'entree du grand portail de ladite Egli≈øe au deuant duquel e≈øtoit vn grand parterre de≈øtine pour faire le mariage, & ou e≈øtoit e≈øleue au de≈ø≈øus vn grand poe≈øle d'vne valeur ine≈øtimable, ≈øous lequel le Roy & Mon≈øieur ≈øon frere quitta Madame, la mirent entre les mains de Mon≈øeigneur le Duc de Cheureu≈øe, & alors Mon≈øieur le Cardinal de la Roche-foucault e≈øpou≈øa Madame, auec les ceremonies ordinaires de l'Egli≈øe.

Dela tout l'ordre cy-de≈ø≈øus s'en alla dedans le coeur par vne longue gallerie qui e≈øt oit allignee au milieu de la Nef de l'Egli≈øe toute couuerte de tapi≈ø≈øerie, la plus bell ‚Ä¢ qui ≈øe peu≈øt iamais voir.

Au milieu dudit coeur e≈øtoient de≈ø-ja placez d'vn co≈øte en des ≈øieges eminents, Me≈ø≈øeigneurs les Pre≈øidents ayant leur mortier d'or ≈øur la te≈øte ve≈øtus de leur robes d'e≈øcatlates doublees d'hermines, & Me≈ø≈øieurs les Con≈øeillers auecques de ≈øemblables robes.
De l'autre co≈øte proi≈ø≈øoit a part Mon≈øieur le Prouo≈øt des Marchands, conuert d'vne longue robe de velours rouge cramoi≈øcy & violet, a≈ø≈øi≈øte des E≈øcheuins du corps de ville.

Dans le coeur de ladite Egli≈øe e≈øtoit e≈øleue de trois marches vn par-terre, au de≈ø≈øus duquel e≈øtoit vn autre grand poe≈øle, ou le Roy, les Roynes, & Mon≈øieur furent placez, & conduits par le≈ødits Duc de Cheurcu≈øe & Amba≈ø≈øadeurs, le≈øquels ≈øe retirenta l'Archeue≈øche iu≈øqu'a ce que le ≈øeruice fut acheue, puis y retournerent trouuer le Roy & les Roynes apres la fin de l'office.
Leurs orai≈øons finies, ils s'en retournerent au me≈øme ordre dedans l'Archeue≈øche, ou toute la Cour ≈øoupa.
Et puis en me≈øme temps, l'on ouyt vn tel bruit des coups de canons qui ≈øe tirerent, que l'on eu≈øt dit que la terre & le ciel ≈øe vouloient ioindre en≈øemble.
Les feus de ioye & d'artifices ≈øe firent par toutes les reus, & l'on peut dire auec verite, que iamais la France n'cu≈øt plus de re≈øiouy≈ø≈øances.
Dieu qui luy a e≈øte tou≈øiours fauourable la maintienne en ≈øa grandeur, & face que ≈øon grand Roy triomphe glorieux de tous ≈øes ennemis, & borne ≈øes terres de l'enclos de tout le monde.

div.head: L'ordre du festin Royal.
div.p: LE ≈øoupper fut dans la grand' Salle lambri≈ø≈øee de l'Archeue≈øche, & la table tenoit d'vn bout a l'autre.

Le Roy e≈øtoit au milieu de la table, ≈øeruy par Mon≈øieur le Grand Prieur, repre≈øentant Mon≈øieur le Grand Mai≈øtre, deuant luy marchoient nombre de tambours, trompettes & clairons, accompagne de Mon≈øieur de Beaumont premier Mai≈øtre d'Ho≈øtel, & trente-deux Mai≈øtres d'Ho≈øtel, tous le ba≈øton a la main.

La viande e≈øtoit portee apres eux par No≈ø≈øeigneurs les Princes, Ducs, Pairs, & Mare≈øchaux de France, ≈øuiuis des Gentils hommes de Cour & ≈øeruans, Mon≈øieur de Ioinuille ≈øeruoit de grand Panetier: Mon≈øieur d'Elbeuf d'E≈øchan≈øon, & Mon≈øieur le Comte d'Arcourt d'E≈øeuyer tranchant.
La Royne Mere au co≈øte droict du Roy, ≈øeruie par Me≈ø≈øieurs le Ducs de Bellegarde, d'Vzais & Luxebourg.
La Royne ≈øur le co≈øte droict de la Royne Mere ≈øeruie par Me≈ø≈øieurs le Ducs d'Aluin, Bri≈ø≈øac, & de Chaune.

La Royne d'Angleterre a co≈øte gauche du Roy, ≈øeruie par Me≈ø≈øieurs les Mare≈øchaux de Vitry, comme grand Panetier: Mon≈øieur le Mare≈øchal d'Auloterre E≈øchan≈øon; & Mon≈øieur de Ba≈ø≈øompierre E≈øcuyer trenchant.
Mon≈øieur le Duc de Cheureu≈øe ≈øous la Reyne d'Angliterre ≈øeruy par le Sieur de R.
Les Amba≈ø≈øadeurs extraordinaires d'Angliterre pres dudit Sieur de Cheureu≈øe.
Mon≈øigneur frere de ≈øa Maje≈øte e≈øtoit a≈ø≈øis aupres de la Royne, & toutes les Prince≈ø≈øes a la table, qui fut ≈øeruy auec quantite de ≈øeruices autant magnifiques que ≈øplendides & Royaux.

div.head: Declaration du Roy, portant defen≈øes √† tous ≈øes ≈øubjets de faire aucun traficq ny commerce au Royaume d'E≈øpagne. Publi√©e en Parliment le douzie≈øme, May, 1625.
div.p:
LOVIS par la grace de Dieu, Roy de France & de Nauarre, A tous ceux qui ces pre≈øentes Lettres verront, Salut. Sur les plaintes qui nous ont e≈øte faictes de la part de plu≈øieurs de nos ≈øubjets traffiquans en E≈øpagne, d'vne Ordonnance decernee le deuxie≈øme de ce mois, par no≈øtre tres-cher & tres-ame bon frere & beaufrere le Roy Catholique, a ≈øes officiers, pour ≈øai≈øir & arre≈øter en ≈øes ports & haures les nauires, effects & marchandi≈øes des Fran√ßois nos ≈øubjets, ≈øous pretexte de repre≈øailles de quelque ≈øomme d'argent que no≈øtre tres-cher & bien-ame Coufin le Duc de Guy≈øe, Gouerneur & no≈øtre Lieutenant general en Prouince, afaict arre≈øter dans des barques es enuirons de no≈øtre ville de Mar≈øeille, comme appertenans a des marchands Geneuois, au≈ø≈øi qu'ils alloient dans les ports des-habitez de no≈øtredit pais de Prouence, au preiudice de nos Ordonnances, & des Arre≈øts de no≈øtre Cour de Parlement d'Aix: Pretendant ledit Roy, que partie dudit argent appartient a ≈øes ≈øubjets (cho≈øe qui n'a point e≈øte verifice) en partie aux Geneuois. Et d'autant qu'il importe pour le bien de nos ≈øubjets, d'empe≈øcher qu'ils ne pui≈ø≈øent receuoir plus grande perte & dommage de la ≈øai≈øie & detention de leurs nauires & biens, qui e≈øt ordonnee en E≈øpagne: a quoy il ne peut e≈øtre plus conuenablement pourueu, que par vne interdiction generale du commerce au lieu ou les marchands nos ≈øubjets ne ≈øont plus en liberte: SCAVOIR fai≈øons, Qu'ayant mis cet affaire en deliberation en no≈øtre Con≈øeil, ou e≈øtoient la Royne no≈øtre tres-honoree Dame & Mere, aucuns Princes de no≈øtre Sang, autres Princes & Officiers de no≈øtre Couronne, Seigneurs & notables per≈øonnages de no≈øtredit Con≈øeil: DE L'ADVIS d'iceluy, & de no≈øtre certaine ≈øcience, pleine pui≈ø≈øance & auctorite
Royale, Nous auons faict & fai≈øons par ce pre≈øentes ≈øignees de no≈øtre main, tres-expre≈ø≈øes inhibitions & defen≈øes a tous nos ≈øubjets de quelque qualite & condition qu'ils ≈øoient, de faire aucun trafficq ny commerce au Royaume d'E≈øpagne, de Bleds, Vins, toyles, cordages: & generalement d'y mener, conduire, tran≈øporter ny achepter aucunes marchandi≈øes de quelque qualite que ce ≈øoit, ≈øur peine aux contreuenans de confi≈øcation de leurs marchandi≈øes, vai≈ø≈øeaux & effects, & d'e≈øtre punis & cha≈øtiez ≈øelon la rigueur de nos Ordonnances, & ≈øe iu≈øques a ce quela main leuee des effects ≈øai≈øis en E≈øpagne ≈øur nos ≈øubjets, aye e≈øte pleinement donnee, & que par nos Lettres patentes Nous en ayons autrement ordonne. SI DONNONS en mandement a nos amez & feaux les gens tenans nos Cours de Parlements, Que ces pre≈øentes ils facent lire, publier & enregi≈øtrer, & le contenu en icelles, garder & executer exactement chacun endroit ≈øoy, & a nos Procureurs generaux ou leurs Sub≈øtituts, de faire pour l'execution d'icelles, toutes pour≈øuites & diligences requi≈øes & nece≈ø≈øaires. Mandons au≈ø≈øi aux Gouuerneurs & nos Lieutenans generaux en nos Prouinces, Capitaines & Gouuerneurs particuliers de nos Villes & places, me≈ømes celles qui ≈øont ≈øur nos frontiers, Baillifs, Sene≈øchaux, Preuo≈øts de nos tres-chers Cou≈øins le Cone≈øtable & Mare≈øchaux de France ou leurs Lieutenans, & a tous autres nos Iu≈øticiers & Officiers & ≈øubiets, de tenir la main a l'execution de ces pre≈øentes: CAR tel e≈øt no≈øtre plai≈øir. En te≈ømoin de quoy, Nous auons faict mettre no≈øtre ≈øeel a ce≈ødites pre≈øentes.
DoÃÑne a Paris le vingt troi≈øie≈øme iour d'Auril, l'an de grace mil ≈øix cens vingt-cinq. Et de no≈øtre regne le quinzie≈øme, Signe, LOVIS. Et ≈øur le reply, Par le Roy, DE LOMENIE.

Et ≈øcellees du grand ≈øceau de cire iaune ≈øur double queue. Et ≈øur ledit reply e≈øt c≈øcrit,
L ‚Ä¢ ues, publices & regi≈øtres √©s Regi≈øtres d'icelle: Ouy, & ce requerant le Procureur General du Roy, pour e≈øtre executees, gardees & ob≈øeruees ≈øelon leur forme & teneur, & copies collationnees d'icelles enuoyees aux Bailliages & Sene≈øchau≈ø≈øees de ce re≈ø≈øort, pour ye≈øtre pareillement leues, publices, regi≈øtrees & executees a la diligence des Sub≈øtituts dudit Procureur General, au≈øquels enionct d'y tenir la main, & d'en certifier la Cour auoir ce faict au mois. A Paris en Parlement le douzie≈øme iour de May mil ≈øix cens vingt-cinq.
Sifine, DV TILLET.
